ARABIC: فَمَا مِنكُم مِّنْ أَحَدٍ عَنْهُ حَٰجِزِينَ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: and not one of you could have protected him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: And not one of you would have been able to stop (Us).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: and not one of you would have been able to withhold Us from doing so.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: None of you would be able to prevent Us from doing this to him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Then none among you would be his saviour.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: And none of you could have prevented it from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: And not one of you could have withheld Us from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: and not one of you could have defended him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: And not one of you could have held Us off from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: and none of you could have held Us off from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: And not one of you would have withheld us from punishing him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: and none of you could have held Us off from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Nor could any of you withhold him (from Our wrath).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: And none of you could withhold Us from (punishing) him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: not one of you could have prevented it from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: And none of you could have restrained Us from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: And there is no one of you who could prevent [Us] from him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [69:47] and not one of you (ahadin is the subject of mā, min being extra, used to emphasise the negation; minkum is a circumstantial qualifier referring to ahadin) could have defended him (hājizīna is the predicate of [the preceding] mā, and it is used in the plural because ahad, when employed in a negatory context, denotes a plural sense; the [suffixed] pronoun in ‘anhu refers to the Prophet), in other words, there is none to prevent Us from punishing him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (And not one of you could have held Us off from him) He says: no one of you could have held Us back from Muhammad (pbuh).
